newsitem.title: GERMANY: SAP sees up to 30 pct 1997 sales growth.
newsitem.headline: SAP sees up to 30 pct 1997 sales growth.

text.p: German business software group SAP AG said on Tuesday it expects sales to rise between 25 percent and 30 percent in 1997 and that pre-tax earnings growth would be a bit stronger.
"The increase in pre-tax profit should be one to two percentage points higher than the growth in sales," SAP board member Henning Kagermann told a news conference in Walldorf.

As previously reported, SAP 1996 group sales were 3.72 billion marks ($2.2 billion), up from 2.696 billion marks the year before. Group net profit rose to 567.5 million marks from 404.8 million and profit on ordinaries rose to 967.2 million marks from 674.1 million.

SAP plans to pay a 50 pfennig higher dividend, boosting the dividend on ordinary shares to 1.80 marks and preferred stock to 1.85 marks. To mark its 25th anniversary, the company will also pay a bonus dividend of 50 pfennigs per share.

SAP gave more details of its 1996 results, saying that cash flow adjusted according to the German Financial Analysts method (DVFA) rose 40 percent to 783 million marks from 559, accounting for 21 percent of turnover.
SAP's results also benefited from the strong dollar. The company said exchange rates boosted sales 58 million marks last year and operating earnings 18 million marks.
